ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I leave the course with a deepened knowledge of how the slave trade impacted the African continent and the extent to which it participated in the perpetuation of African slavery.
I learned much more about slavery from the African perspective

This was perhaps the most interesting course that Ive taken at Yale. I didnt really know anything about the African slave trade prior to taking the course, and I came away with a breadth of knowledge about the subject.

Learned about the development and practice of slavery in Africa, including sources from various tribes and kingdoms in Africa, and how it related to slavery globally (e.g. trans-Atlantic slave trade).

The Atlantic slave trade is often taught through an American lens. However, this course evaluates the trade from the African perspective. As such I learned a great deal about the slave trade in Africa and its affects on the continent.
I better understood the african slave system and how slavery shaped the continent

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: The course was an excellent deep-dive into the African end of the slave trade. The syllabus is clearly conceptualized, the assignments are impactful without being overly stressful, and the class discussions are fascinating.
Very understanding professor, good flow of content for course
I think the biggest strength of the course is the open discussion format. It allows students to respond to the readings in a genuine way.
good workpload and intersting readings
I feel like we would spend more time comprehensively discussing each of the weekly topics. They each were covered very briefly.

Strengths: interesting material and knowledgeable professor

weaknesses: not incredibly engaging and readings are long which means few people do them

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes! We often learn about the slave trade from a Western point of view, but this course challenged my understanding of what the slave trade was, who it impacted, why it was perpetuated, and how it still impacts the world today. If you like history, this is an excellent way to engage with history  especially a topic as important, heavy, and resonant as the slave trade  from a non-Western perspective.
Yes, Robert Harms is chill and very knowledgable on the subject matter
Yes, only if they are interested in learning about slavery and the slave trade.
Yes because its very interesting and you learn A LOT!
Yes. If you do not learn about history, you're doomed to repeat it.
Yes - it's a pretty chill Wr/Hu credit.
yes
If a student is looking for knowledge on the slave trade from a different point of view, then yes, I would.

This is an interesting class that is not very intellectually challenging. If you want a easy writing credit then this is the class for you. If you are genuinely hoping to dive into the material and learn about it then maybe not.
